ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Raman mapping of laser-induced changes and ablation of InAs nanowires

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Indium arsenic (InAs) nanowires were irradiated with a focused laser beam, followed by in situ Raman spectroscopy mapping and scanning electron microscopy imaging to investigate the changes of the nanowires due to laser irradiation. It was found that laser irradiation with the power intensity above a certain threshold causes arsenic (As) atoms to disintegrate from InAs and accumulate on the surface of the nanowire; the accumulated As atoms evaporate under the continued laser irradiation. This process reduces the As content in the nanowire. The reduction of As content, in turn, lowers the melting temperature of the nanowire locally and facilitates laser ablation, which eventually fractures the nanowire. The laser irradiation induced changes of the InAs nanowires are attributed to the local temperature rises due to the irradiation, as confirmed by the Raman peak shifts. The results from this work show that in situ Raman spectroscopy mapping can provide detailed information about the entire process of laser-induced change and ablation of InAs nanowires and has the potential to become a powerful tool for the characterization of laser modification of nanowires and other nanometer-sized objects.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Laser ablation, a process in which the material on a sample surface is removed by laser irradiation, has become a versatile tool for modifying and fabricating the nanostructures of various materials [1, 2]. This technique has been widely used due to several advantages it possesses, such as the easy transferring of a target material composition into products at a low working temperature for high-melting and multi-component materials. Recently, multiple forms of complex oxide films, quantum dots, and one-dimensional nanostructures, such as nanowires, nanotubes, and composite nanostructures, have been fabricated by this technique [3–6].

However, many details of the processes involved in the different stages of laser ablation are still unclear, and the fundamental mechanisms involved in these processes have not yet been completely understood [7]. In particular, if the ablation is performed on a multi-component material using a laser in its continuous wave (CW) mode [8, 9], the irradiation could cause significant local heating to the target, which could subsequently change the local chemical composition of the material. In this case, the laser ablation would be a dynamic process in which the characteristic parameters of the target material change with the irradiation time. Characterization of such processes and understanding the laser-induced changes to the target material are important to many laser ablation related applications such as laser micromachining of materials which involves manipulating and tailoring nanometer-sized objects with precision and modifying their structures and physical properties in order to give the device the desired functions [10–13]. It has been recently demonstrated that local modification and changes of GaAs nanowires can be achieved by shedding a continuous focused laser beam with a modest power density on the nanowire [14, 15]. The results obtained show that laser irradiation increases the local thermal resistance in GaAs nanowires, so that the local thermal conductivity of the nanowires can be manipulated to achieve the optimum thermoelectric effects [14, 15]. However, in order to fine-tune the configuration of a nanometer-sized object for device application, more detailed information about the effects of CW laser irradiation, such as possible changes to chemical composition, and about irradiation parameters, such as the optimum laser power and irradiation time, are needed for a wide range of materials used in nanodevice fabrications. Among these, indium arsenide (InAs) belongs to the same family of groups III–V semiconducting compounds as GaAs; its characteristic narrow band gap and small effective mass of charge carrier have made it particularly suitable for being used in the fabrication of infrared detectors and high-speed, low-power electronic devices [16–18]. Recent efforts have been made to compliment the bulk material properties of InAs with one-dimensional characteristics of nanowires for further enhancing its performance in high-speed and low-power operations [19]. However, successful fabrication of nanodevices using InAs requires further explorations of various approaches for modifying and tailoring InAs nanowires and nanostructured InAs materials.

In this work, we systematically studied the changes of InAs nanowires under the irradiation of a focused laser beam at different intensities and for different time periods using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Raman spectroscopy mapping techniques. In situ Raman mapping technique has been widely used in studying real-time chemical and physical process of materials under various working conditions [20–22]. Combined with high throughput spectrometers which allow recording spectrum in a spectral range from 100 to 5000 cm−1 in the sub-second regime, Raman spectroscopy can be used to simultaneously determine the transient temperature and the chemical reactions on a sample surface [23]. In this study, we find that by irradiating an InAs nanowire with a focused laser beam in a continuous mode, As atoms were separated from InAs crystal and the concentration of As was reduced at the irradiated location on the material. The reduction in As concentration lowers the local melting temperature of the nanowire which facilitates laser modification and ablation of the nanowire. We demonstrate that the entire process of modification and ablation of an InAs nanowire can be characterized in situ by employing a Raman spectroscopy mapping technique. The results indicate that such an approach may lead to novel development and efficient techniques important for nanofabrication and nanotechnology.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: In the experiment, InAs nanowires grown by MOCVD method were first dissolved in an alcohol solution which was subsequently stirred using ultrasound. Most of the nanowires were grown in the [111] crystalline direction; thus their cross-sectional area appears to have a hexagonal shape with sidewall facets belonging to the family of {110} surfaces [24, 25]. The diameter of the wires ranges from a few tens to several hundred nanometers, while the length of the wires is in the range of tens of micrometers. Some of the wires have a needle shape; the diameters of these wires vary from about 500 nm at the root to less than 60 nm at the apex of the tip. The nanowire solution was then deposited onto an Ag-plated silicon wafer; the wafer was then rapidly spanned to eliminate most of the solvent. Afterwards, the nanowire solution deposited substrate was placed in a clean nitrogen flown environment to dry.

The morphology and the chemical composition of the InAs nanowires were characterized using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy dispersion spectrometer (EDS) [26]. After the SEM and EDS characterization, the nanowires were placed inside a scanning atomic force microscopy and Raman spectroscopy mapping system [27]; they were irradiated with a laser in the Raman system at a pre-selected power for a given amount of time. After that, the laser beam was switched to a much lower power (typically below about 1 mW which corresponds to a power density of 5.0×108 mW/cm2) and Raman mapping was performed in situ on the sample by recording Raman spectra at each pixel point as the laser beam scans across the sample.

The Raman system used in this work is equipped with a 532-nm semiconductor laser which was used both as the laser beam in irradiation and as the excitation laser for the Raman spectrometer [27]. The laser beam was focused through a 100×, numerical aperture (NA)=0.95 microscope objective lens. The radial distribution of the focused laser beam has a Gaussian shape. The diameter of the focused laser beam is 500 nm (the edge of the laser beam is defined at where the intensity falls to 1/e 2 (about 13.5 %) of the maximum) [28]. In this work, the radiation power density is calculated by assuming that a uniform power is distributed over a circular area with such a diameter. The Raman spectroscopy mapping was performed by scanning the sample laterally in steps which are controlled by a piezoelectric scanner. At each step, a Raman spectrum is measured. Typically 300×300 steps are taken in completing an entire mapping on a sample. The spatial resolution of Raman mapping, which is determined by the size and profile of exciting laser beam, is found to be about 280 nm, based upon the testing results on a standard sample [27].

Following the Raman characterization, the laser-irradiated nanowires were examined again using SEM and EDS to characterize the changes occurring in the nanowires due to laser irradiation. As will be shown below, a combination of Raman spectroscopy mapping, SEM, and EDS allows for detailed investigations of morphological and chemical composition changes of the nanowires after laser irradiation.

Section2.Heading: Raman peak shift due to laser-induced local temperature rise
Section2.Para:
Figure 1(a) shows an SEM micrograph of a typical needle-shaped InAs nanowire on an Ag-plated silicon wafer; the upper left inset is an enlarged image of the portion of the nanowire indicated in the image, and the lower right inset is the schematic drawing of the laser irradiation geometry. Figure 1(b) is an EDS taken on the same nanowire. The Ag and Si elements in the EDS are from Ag-plated silicon substrate. Aside from a small amount of carbon and oxygen which are from the residue of the solvent, the vast majority elements present in the nanowires were In and As, as shown in the EDS.
Fig. 1
(a) SEM micrograph of an InAs nanowire with an enlarged part of it shown in the inlet on the upper left, and the schematic illustration of the scattering geometry of the measurement in the inlet on the lower right. (b) EDS and (c) a Raman spectrum taken from the nanowire shown in (a)

The Raman spectra on the InAs nanowires of diameters ranging from several tens to several hundred nanometers exhibit the same characteristic features observed in bulk crystalline InAs and in the nanowire InAs samples reported previously [24, 29]. A representative Raman spectrum obtained on the nanowire shown in Fig. 1(a) is presented in Fig. 1(c). The dots are the experimental results and the solid line is a Lorentzian fit to the experimental data in the range from 150 to 300 cm−1. The dominant features in the spectrum are a strong peak at 214 cm−1 and a weak peak at 238 cm−1; both peaks are very close to the Raman peaks that correspond to transverse optical (TO) and longitudinal optical (LO) modes of the lattice vibrations in bulk InAs, which are found to be at 217 and 238 cm−1, respectively [24, 29–31]. Therefore, these two peaks can be assigned to the same optical modes in zinc blende (ZB) structure of InAs nanowire [24]. The downward shift by about 3 cm−1 in the TO mode in comparison to the corresponding bulk mode was also observed in a recent Raman spectroscopy study of InAs nanowires and was attributed to the wurtzite (WZ) structure of the nanowires [29].

When the laser power in the Raman spectrometer was kept at a constant level and below 1.0 mW (power density 5.0×108 mW/cm2), the variation of TO peak measured along an InAs wire was found to be typically within about 1 cm−1. However, as power of the excitation laser increases to above 1.5 mW (power density 7.5×108 mW/cm2), the TO peak shows a systematic shift towards lower wave numbers. Figure 2 depicts Raman spectra obtained from the same location of an InAs nanowire with diameter of 500 nm while the laser power was increased from 1.5 mW (7.5×108 mW/cm2) to 5.5 mW (2.75×109 mW/cm2). Within this range of power density, the TO peak shifts almost linearly from 214 to 209.5 cm−1 and the LO peak shifts synchronously as TO mode from 238 to 234 cm−1. The power dependence of the shift suggests that it is a temperature effect; laser irradiation raises the temperature of the irradiated region of the nanowire. The same effect has been observed in recent study of GaAs nanowires [14, 15]. In fact, a rather accurate account of the local temperature rise on the GaAs nanowire due to laser irradiation was obtained by measuring the shifts in both Stokes and anti-Stokes Raman peaks simultaneously [32].
Fig. 2
Raman spectra obtained at the same spot of an InAs nanowire while the laser power was increased from 1.5 mW (7.5×108 mW/cm2) to 5.5 mW (2.75×109 mW/cm2)

The temperature rises in the InAs nanowire due to laser irradiation depend on the configuration of the nanowire and its contact with the substrate and the environment and other factors. To obtain a semi-quantitative assessment of the temperature effect, we calculated the temperature rise of an InAs nanowire due to the local heating from a focused laser beam shed on the side of the wire by solving the heat diffusion equation using a finite element analysis (FEA) method [33]. In the calculation, both the boundary resistance between nanowire facet and the Ag-plated Si substrate and the thermal conductance due to surrounding air are assumed to be negligible, and the substrate temperature remains at a constant 300 K, as shown in Fig. 3(a). The temperature rises due to the radiation depend on the optical absorption or the reflectivity of the substance. The reflectivity of InAs at 532 nm was found to be 0.411 [34], thus in the calculation we assumed that 40 % of the energy from the laser beam is reflected from the surfaces of the nanowire. Solving the heat diffusion equation gives the heat flow pattern, and the isothermal profiles in the nanowire are shown in Fig. 3(b). The parameters that affect the temperature variation and the isothermal profile in the nanowire are the laser power density and the thermal conductivity and the diameter (from a vertex through the center to the other vertex on the opposite side) of the InAs wire.
Fig. 3
(a) The settings of the boundary conditions used in the FEA model calculation of temperature rise induced by laser irradiation. (b) The side view of the calculated isothermal profile inside a nanowire. The substrate is assumed to be at a constant temperature and not affected by laser irradiation

Using the reported thermal conductivity of ZB structure in InAs nanowire, which is approximately 10 W m−1 K−1 [35], we calculated the temperature rises for different sizes of the InAs wires and under different laser power densities. The solid line in Fig. 4 is the calculated result. The local temperature of the nanowire can be determined from the shift of the Raman peaks if their temperature dependence is known. Thus, using the reported temperature dependence of the Raman peak shift for ZB structure in InAs, which is −0.009 cm−1/K [36], the local temperatures of the InAs nanowires under the irradiation of different laser power densities were determined from the TO peak shifts and are plotted in Fig. 4. Also plotted in the figure are the calculated results using the above described FEA method. These results show reasonable agreement between the temperature rises calculated using the FEA method and that determined from shifts of the Raman peak.
Fig. 4
The local temperature of an InAs wire with diameter of 500 nm irradiated with a 532-nm light of different power densities, determined from the shift of the TO peaks in the Raman spectra; the solid line is the local temperature calculated using the FEA method

Section1.Heading: Accumulation and evaporation of As on the surfaces of InAs nanowires
Section1.Para:
As the laser power further increases, the SEM micrograph on the laser irradiated region shows no obvious morphological change, but the Raman spectra across the laser irradiated region shows some noticeable changes. Figure 5 shows the SEM micrographs and Raman spectroscopy images obtained at a location on an InAs nanowire which was irradiated by the focused laser beam with power density of 3.5×109 m W/cm2 for 10 seconds are shown. The SEM micrograph (Fig. 5(a)) displays that the nanowire morphology remains intact. However, the Raman spectra (Fig. 5(d)) taken on the laser-irradiated region reveals two peaks, at 198 and 252 cm−1. The positions of these peaks are in agreement with those of the characteristic Raman peaks of E g(TO) and A 1g(LO) modes in As crystals [37]. The Raman spectroscopy images shown in Figs. 5(b) and (c) are the integration of the Raman signals at each pixel in the ranges from 150 to 300 cm−1 and from 205 to 225 cm−1, respectively. The bright spots indicated as (1) and (3) in Fig. 5(b) are caused by the two Raman peaks of the E g(TO) and A 1g(LO) modes. The Raman spectroscopy image shown in Fig. 5(c) is the integration of the Raman signals at each pixel in the range from 205 to 225 cm−1, which covers the TO peak of InAs only and displays a uniform InAs background, showing that no change has occurred to the TO mode of InAs in the sample. Thus, two Raman peaks and corresponding bright spots in the Raman mapping are the indication that As atoms separate from InAs and migrate to the surface of the nanowire under the laser irradiation.
Fig. 5
(a) An SEM micrograph obtained at the same location on an InAs nanowire which was irradiated by a focused laser beam with power density of 7.0 mW (3.5×109 mW/cm2) for 10 seconds. The integration bands of Raman signal are (b) from 150 to 300 cm−1 and (c) from 205 to 225 cm−1. (d) The Raman spectra of three different positions selected from part (b)

As the laser power further increases, both the morphological and chemical changes occur to the nanowire in the region irradiated by the laser. Figures 6(a) and (b) shows the SEM micrograph and Raman spectroscopy images taken at the same location on an InAs nanowire irradiated by the laser at 13.5 mW (6.75×109 mW/cm2) for 10 seconds. The SEM micrograph clearly shows that the materials had been ablated away from the nanowire at this laser power. The Raman spectra display a drastic variation across the laser-irradiated spot: the Raman spectroscopy image from 150 to 300 cm−1 reveals that the bright spots which correspond to presence of crystalline As at the center of the irradiation region separate into two where the Raman peaks corresponding to crystalline As become much stronger, but in the region between the two bright spots, these Raman peaks almost disappear as shown in Fig. 6(c).
Fig. 6
(a) The SEM micrographs and (b) Raman spectroscopy images obtained at the same location as those in Fig. 5 on an InAs nanowire which was irradiated by the focused laser beam with power density of 13.5 mW (6.75×109 mW/cm2) for 10 seconds. The integration band of Raman signal is from 150 to 300 cm−1. (c) The Raman spectra of three different positions selected from part (b)

Figure 7 shows a series of Raman spectroscopy images obtained by integrating the Raman signals from 150 to 300 cm−1 at each pixel at the same location of an InAs nanowire irradiated by the laser at power of 8.5 mW (4.25×109 mW/cm2), 9.5 mW (4.75×109 mW/cm2), 10.5 mW (5.25×109 mW/cm2), 11.5 mW (5.75×109 mW/cm2), 12.5 mW (6.25×109 mW/cm2) and 13.5 mW (6.75×109 mW/cm2), consecutively; the irradiation time at each power setting was 10 seconds.
Fig. 7
A series of Raman spectroscopy images obtained by integrating Raman signal from 150 to 300 cm−1 at each pixel at the same location of the same InAs nanowire irradiated by the laser at power of (a) 8.5 mW (4.25×109 mW/cm2), (b) 9.5 mW (4.75×109 mW/cm2), (c) 10.5 mW (5.25×109 mW/cm2), (d) 11.5 mW (5.75×109 mW/cm2), (e) 12.5 mW (6.25×109 mW/cm2) and (f) 13.5 mW (6.75×109 mW/cm2), consecutively; the irradiation time at each power setting was 10 seconds

Figure 8(a) shows an SEM micrograph of the nanowire irradiated by the laser at 12 mW for one second. The energy dispersion spectra (EDS) taken at three different spots along the wire are depicted in Fig. 8(b), which reveals that As content in the center of the irradiated region decreases. So, by combining the results shown in Figs. 5–7, we can conclude that the laser irradiation effect on InAs nanowire can be described as follows: laser irradiation on an InAs nanowire creates a temperature profile in the nanowire, as illustrated in Fig. 3. It seems that As atoms were separated from InAs and accumulated at the surface of the nanowire under the irradiation, although the mechanisms that cause the separation are not entirely clear [38–40]. Continuous laser irradiation causes the As atoms to evaporate from the center of the irradiated region where the temperature is the highest; the As atoms re-deposited in the area near the edge of the laser irradiated spot where the temperature is lower. The process is dictated by the temperature profile created by laser irradiation.
Fig. 8
(a) An SEM micrograph of the nanowire irradiated by the laser at 12 mW for 1 second. (b) The EDS spectra taken at three different spots along the wire shown in part (a)

Section2.Heading: Laser power threshold that initiates composition changes of the nanowire
Section2.Para:
As discussed above, laser irradiation of the nanowire causes local temperature rises which subsequently induced chemical changes in the wires. The minimum laser power needed to raise the local temperature sufficiently for the composition change to occur should be dependent on the thermal transport property and the size of the nanowire. We determine such a minimum power threshold for a given sized nanowire by linearly extrapolating the magnitude of the Raman peak due crystalline As in the spectra obtained on the nanowire versus the laser power density. The results of the threshold power density versus different size of InAs nanowires are plotted in Fig. 9. An important feature shown in the figure is that a laser irradiation with power density on the order of 3.25×109 mW/cm2 is high enough to cause chemical changes to InAs wires with diameter in the range of a few hundred nanometers or less.
Fig. 9
The threshold laser power density to cause laser ablation on an InAs nanowire vs. the diameter of the nanowire

Section2.Heading: Fracture of the nanowire due to laser ablation
Section2.Para:
Continuous laser irradiation at the above power threshold eventually leads to a fracture of the nanowire. Figure 10 illustrates the different stages of the fracture process of the same nanowire. The fracture is obviously caused by continuous removal of materials from the nanowire via sublimation due to laser heating. If the laser power density is set at 3×109 mW/cm2 and the diameter of the wire is 500 nm, the temperature at the laser-irradiated spot could reach about 850 K (temperature rise ΔT is 550 K), based upon the calculation results shown in Fig. 3(b). This estimated temperature rise, although appreciable, is still considerably lower than the melting temperature of InAs, which is 1215 K [41]; but it is higher than the melting temperature of pure In. Thus, the effect of laser ablation on the nanowire at a relatively low power density is consistent with the results of Raman spectra and EDS, which show a significant reduction of As content in the center of the irradiated spot. Such a reduction of As content lowers the local melting temperature of the InAs nanowire significantly to a value close to that of pure In.
Fig. 10
SEM micrographs of an InAs wire after being laser-irradiated at different power for specified radiation time. (a) 10 mW for 1 second; (b) 10 mW for additional 10 seconds; (c) 12 mW for 1 second; and (d) 15 mW for 1 second. The InAs nanowire shown in the SEM micrographs is the same one but at different stages of the fracturing process due to the laser irradiation

Reduction of As content in the center of irradiated spot can be caused by the evaporation of As due to laser heating. It is well known that thermal treatment of the groups III–V semiconductor may lead to evaporation of group V element [42]. At low temperatures, the vapor pressures for groups III and V are small, and evaporation from the material surface can be neglected [43]. At raised temperatures, the vapor pressure above groups III–V materials is dominated by that of the more volatile group V element such as P, As or Sb. The partial pressures of these group V elements are generally many orders of magnitude higher than those of group III elements such as In, Ga or Al, so that group V element evaporates easily at the higher temperatures, typically in the forms of two- or four-atom groups (e.g. As2, As4) [42]. Laser-induced As evaporation in bulk group III–V family compound semiconductor material such as GaAs and InAs have been investigated using Raman scattering and time-resolved reflectivity techniques [44]. It has been shown that at the threshold laser power, As atoms evaporate from the surfaces of these compounds, leaving the low melting point In component behind [43–45]; the lower melting temperature of the nanowire facilitates the laser ablation and the eventual fracture of the nanowire. The results obtained in our study are consistent with these results [44–46].

Section1.Heading: Summary
Section1.Para: We have shown that Raman spectroscopy mapping can be a very useful technique for characterizing in situ the composition and morphological changes of InAs nanowires caused by the irradiation of the focused laser beam from the same Raman system. The effects of the laser irradiation at 532 nm wavelength to InAs nanowires can be summarized as follows: laser irradiation raises the local temperature on the irradiated spot of the nanowire; the temperature rises proportionally with the laser power. When the laser power density is above a certain threshold, As atoms separate from InAs and accumulate at the surface of the nanowire. Further increasing the laser power or increasing the irradiation time causes As atoms to evaporate from the central region of the irradiated spot, resulting in a reduction of As concentration in the nanowire. Such reduction of As makes the center of laser-irradiated region In-rich, which, in turn, lowers the local melting temperature of the nanowire and facilitates laser ablation and the eventual fracture of the nanowire. This process may be fine-tuned to tailor InAs and other nanowires in their compositions and morphologies for specific applications in nanotechnologies.
